title: Man Utd upset the odds again as Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's mini-revival continues
text:

First Liverpool, now this.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is getting quite good at upsetting the odds.

Two-goal Marcus Rashford conjured up his inner Cristiano Ronaldo to leave Chelsea in pieces and Manchester United in the Carabao Cup quarter-finals - just as the Reds’ mini-revival looked set to be exposed as yet another false dawn.

Let’s not kid ourselves, after establishing themselves for two decades as the team you simply could not ever write off, United of late have been the side you could no longer trust.

After wins in September over Leicester and Astana, for example, they were winless in five ahead of their unexpected draw at Liverpool.

(Image: Getty Images)

But here they were excellent to ease the pressure on their boss. Defensively disciplined and deserving of their success. They’ll fancy Bournemouth in their Saturday lunchtime showdown on the south coast.

With just one win from their previous eleven trips to Stamford Bridge in all competitions, you had to be either brave or a die-hard fan to back them here with Frank Lampard’s side on a run of seven straight wins.

Lampard had warned his players were “a million miles” away from the side beaten 4-0 at Old Trafford in August.

Here, though, the United players wanted it more. Lampard acknowledged Rashford’s free-kick from around 25 yards into the top corner, with 17 minutes left, as being “special” and rightly so.

(Image: Getty Images)

But maybe the Chelsea players had turned up expecting to win. What other explanation could there be for the Blues’ failure to get a single shot on target during the first 45 minutes?

United may have won at Partizan Belgrade in the Europa League and Norwich in the Premier League but with their fragile confidence they were there for the taking.

With the likes of Mason Mount and Tammy Abraham on the bench, however, Chelsea could not even test them.

Propelled by a wall of noise from the travelling fans behind them. United were resolute at the back and stronger in midfield.

When they needed that little bit of luck in the final third, Daniel James provided it. The Wales winger drove into the Chelsea box on 25 minutes with young defender Marc Guehi in front of him and seemingly nowhere to go.

(Image: REUTERS)

Thundering in behind him, however, came Marcos Alonso with a challenge he simply did not need to make. Down went James and out stretched the hand of referee Paul Tierney towards the penalty spot.

Marcus Rashford drilled low into the bottom corner as Willy Caballero went the other way.

Chelsea finally turned up for work in the second half with Marcos Rojo forced to block from Billy Gilmour and Callum Hudson-Odoi volleying narrowly over the bar from the edge of their box amid an assault on the United goal.

The United hinges were creaking as Chelsea kept banging on the door.

(Image: Getty Images)

They smashed it open on 61 minutes when Michy Batshuayi gained possession on the half-way line, outpaced Harry Maguire, Victor Lindelof and Marcos Rojo and powered the ball low into the bottom corner from outside the box. Brilliant goal.

It would take a special goal to upstage it and Rashford’s banger did just that.

It was an effort worthy of settling any game. What a shame Solskjaer didn’t fancy facing the press at the end to accept the credit he and his team deserved.
description: United's win over Chelsea was their third away victory in a row following a run of 11 games without tasting victory on the road
